stem: The nurse is caring for a client in labor exhibiting late decelerations. Select the 4 most appropriate actions the nurse should take.

options.text: Administer oxygen via non-rebreather mask at 10 L/min.
Increase the rate of the maintenance IV fluid infusion.
Place the client in a supine position.
Discontinue oxytocin if it is being administered.
Document the findings and continue to monitor.
Turn the client to a left lateral position.

tabs.name: SBAR
tabs.content: Situation: Jane Doe, a 28-year-old G1P0 at 39 weeks gestation, is experiencing late decelerations. Background: Admitted at 07:00 for induction of labor due to post-dates. Started on Pitocin at 2 mU/min at 08:00, currently at 16 mU/min. Membranes ruptured spontaneously at 09:30 with clear fluid. Assessment: Currently 4 cm dilated, 80% effaced, and -2 station. Maternal vital signs are stable: BP 120/80, HR 88, RR 18, Temp 98.8°F. Fetal heart rate baseline is 130 bpm with moderate variability. Late decelerations noted starting at 10:15, coinciding with contractions. Pain level is reported as 7/10. Recommendation: Requesting orders for intrauterine resuscitation measures and evaluation by the provider. Consider decreasing or discontinuing Pitocin. Continuous fetal monitoring in place. Last dose of pain medication (IV fentanyl) was at 09:00. Patient denies any allergies. 10:30

tabs.name: Vitals
tabs.content: BP: 120/80 mmHg, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18 breaths/min, Temp: 98.8°F (37.1°C), SpO2: 99% on room air. Fetal Heart Rate: Baseline 130 bpm, moderate variability, late decelerations present.

tabs.name: Labs
tabs.content: CBC and electrolytes within normal limits upon admission. Group B Streptococcus: Positive.

tabs.name: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Patient alert and oriented. Cardiovascular: Regular heart rate and rhythm. Respiratory: Clear lung sounds bilaterally. Abdomen: Contractions palpable, fundal height appropriate for gestational age. Genitourinary: Ruptured membranes, clear fluid noted. Cervical exam: 4 cm dilated, 80% effaced, -2 station.

tabs.name: Care Plan
tabs.content: Continuous fetal monitoring, assess maternal vital signs every 30 minutes, monitor labor progress, administer pain medication as ordered, prepare for potential interventions based on fetal heart rate patterns.

tabs.name: MAR
tabs.content: Oxytocin: 16 mU/min IV. Fentanyl: 50 mcg IV at 09:00.

rationale.option_1: Correct: Administering oxygen via non-rebreather mask at 10 L/min increases the oxygen available to the fetus, which can help improve fetal oxygenation during late decelerations.
rationale.option_2: Correct: Increasing the rate of the maintenance IV fluid infusion can improve maternal blood volume and placental perfusion, which can help address the underlying cause of late decelerations.
rationale.option_3: Incorrect: Placing the client in a supine position can compress the vena cava, reducing blood flow to the uterus and potentially worsening late decelerations. The client should be placed in a lateral position to optimize blood flow.
rationale.option_4: Correct: Discontinuing oxytocin, if being administered, reduces uterine contractions, which can decrease fetal stress and improve fetal oxygenation during late decelerations. Oxytocin-induced tachysystole can cause late decelerations.
rationale.option_5: Incorrect: Preparing for immediate delivery may be necessary if other interventions are ineffective, but it is not the first action. Intrauterine resuscitation should be attempted first to improve fetal status.
rationale.option_6: Incorrect: Notifying the healthcare provider is important and should be done concurrently, but it is not the immediate first action. Intrauterine resuscitation should be initiated while simultaneously notifying the provider.
rationale.option_7: Incorrect: While documentation and monitoring are important, they are not the priority actions when late decelerations are present. Immediate interventions are needed to improve fetal oxygenation and address the underlying cause.
rationale.option_8: Correct: Turning the client to a left lateral position can improve blood flow to the uterus and placenta, which can help address the underlying cause of late decelerations and improve fetal oxygenation.
rationale.correct: Clinical rationale: Late decelerations indicate uteroplacental insufficiency. The priority is to improve fetal oxygenation through intrauterine resuscitation measures: administering oxygen, increasing IV fluids, discontinuing oxytocin (if applicable), and repositioning the mother to a lateral position. The provider should be notified concurrently.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Many students will think notifying the provider is the first action, but in this case, the nurse must take immediate action to resuscitate the fetus first and simultaneously notify the provider. Prioritize interventions to improve fetal oxygenation.

mnemonic.title: HINT
mnemonic.expansion: LION (Left lateral, Increase IV fluids, Oxygenate, Notify provider) is a helpful mnemonic for remembering the initial steps in managing late decelerations. Remember to implement LION interventions concurrently with notifying the provider.

clinicalPearls: Late decelerations indicate uteroplacental insufficiency. Intrauterine resuscitation aims to improve fetal oxygenation by optimizing maternal blood volume, oxygenation, and reducing uterine activity. Remember LION: Left lateral, Increase IV fluids, Oxygenate, Notify provider.
